Params[3]: The three rush toward Medical Center 09 with the only survivor.
What happened? Who's this?
I came across a squad that had been assaulted, and most of them were dead by the time I got there.
Having heard the noise here, some of the refugees gather around.
Let me help.
I appreciate your sense of humor, but you should probably just stay out of this.
Out of the way. She was a technician in the reservation area before coming to the Medzone.
And she was 100 times better than you, Talbot!
Ugh...
Haha, boy, I'm sure I'm not even half as good. Let's get to work already. How's she doing? Is there anything wrong with her M.I.N.D.?
She's got damage all over her body. Some of them seem old, and I'm still working on figuring out the others.
Right. Let me take care of this part, and you can handle the rest of it.
Okay!
Lillian turns around and pulls over a medical cart, and begins working away with this technician who hasn't made her name known.
What's with that face? Didn't think this place would be so different, eh?
I sure never saw this coming. Look at all these new faces we have. We're definitely bigger but more organized as a group now.
A lot of them came out when the train collapsed, and we decided to assign them all to different bases because God only knew how long it would take for the train to work again.
The train...
Talbot fell silent at the mention of the train.
It all happened out of the blue. We ended up with a whole bunch of injured people while short on supplies. It was a total mess.
Most of the humans have recovered already and are sharing the workload... The whole situation hasn't really gotten better since, but we've been coping just fine by helping each other out.
What are you all doing here, by the way?
It's our turn to guard the place.
Oh. Where is the guy that came with you?
Talbot looks over at the young man—who's now talking with one of the medics in the Medzone.
Busy changing wound dressings for a little boy, the man doesn't notice what people are saying about him.
Is he your new captain or just a new member? Doesn't seem like he's having any trouble hanging out with humans.
I don't know who he is. Only just met him on our way here. Lillian said he doesn't even remember his own name because of memory loss.
Thought you guys finally found someone to be your new capt.
The higher-ups ain't got no time to make us a new team now. They just make do with whoever they can find.
Saying no more, Talbot keeps himself busy wiping his weapon.
Totes feel you. I mean, it's been a while since the incident at Pulia Forest Park Ruins, and the higher-ups are still having a hard time dealing with things efficiently.
Right, and that's because they've taken in way too many refugees, and putting them all back on track hasn't been exactly easy.
Things are getting better, though. Traffic between the sky and the ground has resumed partially, and we've seen supplies and weapons replenished.
Alrighty, done with basic check-ups and treatment here. Her M.I.N.D. is still a mess, and it's a miracle that she's conscious at all.
What's your name?
Which squad were you on before?
My squad... they're all...
Unable to even string her words into a proper sentence, the girl starts crying.
Let's save that question for later. Her M.I.N.D. isn't exactly stable yet, and we don't have a commandant here. Let's leave her to rest for now.
Next person in line?
Coming.
The young man puts down the medical instrument he was holding, then walks up toward the medical table and sits down beside the girl.
Man, all these people with unstable M.I.N.D. these days.
Dude, just try to imagine the damage seeing your teammates cut into pieces can do to your M.I.N.D.

Boy, I'm damn sure we're going to end up with just a few more defectors if things keep up the way they do. We have no updates on the Omega Weapon so far, and I don't see why we need to keep being hopeful about it.
Are you saying that defecting is any better? Where are we supposed to go? Where is safe even?
We turn to Ascendants, of course.
Oh, c'mon...
C'mon what? The parliament has already taken in Transcendants like Camu!
Things would be a lot easier if someone could just become an Ascendant and rein 'em Corrupted!
I know what you mean, but none of those defectors came back here to help us.
What if it's because they couldn't? Intel says only a handful of them passed that "filtering", right?
But those that did could have come back here to help us, right?
Ascendants can only be our enemies.
That's just how you see it, though. If I were an Ascendant, I'd have the freedom to use it however I pleased.
I know we aren't out of harm's way yet, and I probably don't have a second choice, but I'm willing to take whatever comes my way, so long as I can do something to fix this disaster.
Why do you sound like you already have a plan?
I knew it... C'mon, just drop that already. Only thing you'd become is a Corrupted if you go, and we'd have no choice but to get rid of you.
What if I don't become a Corrupted, though?
What makes you think you'd be one of the few lucky ones, kid?
I have no idea what these Ascendants you're talking about are capable of, but Punishing has been around for years already, and we'd have seen a savior by now already if that idea were meant to work.
You need to take it slowly, son. That's just how things work.
You think you know me?!
Talbot throws a punch at the wall, drawing people's attention. Then, silence ensues.
Take it slow, huh? Someone dies with every second that passes, and you're telling me to take it slow?!
C'mon, Talbot...

What has taking it slow done for us? What have we stopped? The Corrupted did drop in number, but we now have Hetero-Creatures and the Red Tide to deal with. There is no end to getting rid of Punishing!
People are dying and we can't do a damn thing about it!
Talbot, Master! She died! Master died!
Had I known the train was going to collapse, I would have done everything I could to stop Anna and the elite squad from escorting the Forsaken!
But I didn't. I failed at protecting her...
Wait, what train...?
Talbot, enough with all that nonsense!
We could have sent you down to the Purifying Force for saying all that you just said! And the old man didn't mean ill. He's right.
We'd have seen a savior already if being gifted is the only thing you need to pass the filtering.
Being an Ascendant isn't the way out, and there is only so much that a Transcendant can do. We need to figure out a different way to save more people.
Now, apologize to the man—and empty your mind of that childish thought at once. If this ever happens again, I'll have no choice but to call the Purifying Force on you.
Why you little...
I'm sorry.
Saying not another word, Talbot walks away with all eyes on him.
Hey, Talbot!
Lillian rushes up after Talbot.
Where are you going?
The man was about to go after them when the technician holds him back down.
Nuh-uh, we aren't done with your check-ups yet.
Let's go!
Already on it!
T-Talbot...
...Sigh.
Don't be sad. They've been going on and on about these days and haven't worked out a single plan. It's the same old thing as it was years ago.
They show you an incentive you can't possibly refuse and make us believe that everyone will get a cut of it if we all work a bit—while they're in fact just sending us straight to the slaughterhouse.
Haha, that sounds like a Ponzi scheme. You're talking about "Blessing Boxes", right?
Blessing Boxes...?
Mind you, that thing is more than a Ponzi scheme. There's gambling, and it can really eat you and your family up whole.
The aristocrats make them sell those things, right? I heard that's Ashlar's idea, but how does that have anything to do with all these Ascendants they were talking about?
Nothing, but they're the same in principle—they can both eat you up.
The lucky one becomes the aristocrats' dog—and the other 9,999 all get eaten up whole.
The aristocrats...?
Constructs don't need to leave it to the hand of luck to draw "tickets", at least.
Yeah, and that's because they need to do that at the cost of possibly losing their lives.
Do we stand a chance to win, then?
Not if things don't change. It's just like how things were back then, right? They all just fought... and died, period.
The train... Right, I remember it now.
Listening to people's discussion, the young man closes his eyes as memories flood over him.
The "Blessing Box"...
It's one of the things that caused the lower level to rot.
I probably heard about "Blessing Box" for the first time before I was nine...
But when was it exactly...? It's been so long... and I can't remember it now.
Back then, conflicts between the upper and lower levels were mostly personal. The lower level wasn't as crowded, and the guards from the upper level were pretty well-mannered.
Mom said ACA had been "on the verge of chaos—but never truly crossed the line."
This is your workspace for today. Everything is in there and organized, and you'll all be paid for the amount of work you do. Thank you all so much.
The guard walks into the cargo car with the dozen of selected ones. In there, they see piles of goods and some recycled paper boxes.
Alright, "Blessing Boxes" again. Gotta love easy jobs like this!
Right. Since this job is relatively easy and the pay is calculated based on how much work you do, Boss wanted us to get a few kids with too much time on their hands to do these for extra earnings.
Of course, and we'd be happy to bring some old hands here, too. They don't have another source of income other than those easy tasks from the Logistics Crew, anyway.
Copy that. Sounds like a plan, actually. I'll tell Boss about that.
With a nod, the guard turns around and leaves.
Do we only need to stuff the things from the bigger box into these "Blessing Boxes"?

Yes. You just need to fold up these recycled boxes, wipe off any filthy traces on them, stuff the things from the chest into the boxes, and then seal them up. And keep in mind that you're only supposed to stuff one of each item into a single box.
Right. Thank you.
Didn't think I'd see a kid this age here.
We're totally fine with it. This job is easy enough, and it wouldn't hurt to have some extra earnings.
With a paper box in his hands, the boy looks into the bigger box with all sorts of things. The bigger box holds a lot of simple parts, loose medications, and old everyday products.
Those things are as good as useless, but other than that, there is a deck of shiny cards sitting neatly in a metal box with a tantalizing shine.
Sir, what are these cards?
They're "Blessing Cards".
Blessing Cards?
Yes. There are only so many of them, and you need to be really lucky to have one in the Blessing Box you buy.
And if you do get one in the lot box you buy, you get to board the train with the card and live with everyone.
Why do you need a Blessing Card to live with everyone, though?
Haha, son, consider yourself lucky for being a native on the train. You've no idea what's going on out there.
But I do. Mom told me about what's going on out there, but I still don't know why you need a Blessing Card to board the train.
Because we only have so many seats on the train, and they need "tickets" to board. Have you heard about these tickets?
He nods earnestly.
There aren't many livable places out there. See, if you go to places like refugee bases, medzones, or reservation areas, you'll see that they only take in skilled workers that are young enough.

And even if they're nice enough to take you in, they won't be able to keep you around for long—because with all sorts of things in short supply, no one wants to keep someone around that can't help with anything.
Which is why the safer the place you go to, the more they want to make sure you really are skilled.
And you get to stay there if you pass the screening—but the problem is that there are a bunch of people who either failed or have no family members who passed the screening.

And it's not necessarily the case that they aren't capable of anything. Wherever they went to was probably just a bad fit for them, and it's much too risky for them to travel far away from home for job hunting.
And so they want to hop on the train and go somewhere else?
Exactly, and the train never stops hiring. You'd have to pass the screening, though, of course.
Be it the Cargo Crew, Maintenance Crew, Logistics Crew, or the guards or the service staff up there—they only want people with the right skills and physical condition.
What happens if someone just can't pass a single screening?
Then physical work it is, then, and they're actually short on hands these days.
Most physical jobs are one-shot deals, though, which is why people don't keep workers around to meet these ad hoc needs.

If someone is lucky enough to get one of the tickets we stuff into one of the boxes, they can hop onboard and either go to live somewhere safe without having to go through the screening, or form a nomadic squad with others and do their part to help.

And the upper level stands to gain part of the supplies, while the lower level gets a few extra hands that can go and help people around. The elder folks and kids would then be able to come and help with making "Blessing Boxes", which makes it possible for everyone to get supplies.
I like how that sounds!
They're all happy and excited about the future.
After that day...
With the Blessing Box gaining traction, the lower level starts growing crowded.
They're now seeing an influx of people who failed to pass screenings at other places, and most of the skills they possess do not align with the skills they need to work on the train.
To help these people stay above water, the aristocrats form a "Bumblebee" squad that takes in everyone without a stable job.

Bumblebee does all sorts of outsourced work—be it rebuilding reservation areas, helping with farming, removing ruins from the road that stand in the Cargo Crew's way, or working as ad hoc mercenaries.
Most of these people, however, either stay behind in the Industrial Carriage, or head down to all the factories to do simple odd jobs in place of machines that don't work anymore.
Things have so far turned out the way everyone had expected them to.
Except these "simple" odd jobs quickly get out of hand.
Without a proper screening process that filters out those who just aren't meant to be here, the Bumblebee now has quite a few members that are... less than cooperative.
Yo, I got humiliated good at the reservation area I was at yesterday.
Because of "Bumblebee"?
Damn straight. This guy was helpin' on the farm with us at the base, and dude was rollin' on the ground whining about how tired he was after getting his pay.
Haha, ain't no surprise at all. A winner would never even think about buyin' a Blessing Box. You know what I'm talkin' about?
You'd only buy a Blessing Box if you're too young—in which case you were born havin' no school to go to, where you'd have been able to pick up a skill.

Or you're too old—in which case you've spent the prime of your life either doin' some creative job, performances, or game designin', except these are all things that could have only kept you alive back in peaceful times.
I have full respect for all sorts of occupations, and I came across a bunch of these people working different lines of work before going to the reservation area.
I'm talkin' about those that haven't found themselves a job and are still refusing to be Scavengers.
Dude, it's a miracle that these people haven't caused any big scene at all doin' physical work. Totes normal that some of them crack doin' it.
Did you just say it's "normal"? Well, logically speakin', yes, but I'm talkin' about whether they're good fits for the job. See, it's no different than throwing dirt on ACA's reputation.

And guess what? The Cargo Crew is gettin' dragged through the mud because of all these. When people from reservation areas know we're from ACA now, they just assume we're all a bunch of jerks without botherin' to check our affiliation.

Gotta put up with that, and we need to give them credit for even getting out there to work at all—they're definitely farin' a lot better than those good-for-nothings that stay behind in the car and steal people's bread from under the pillow.
They're a hopelessly useless bunch, and those bases got some real nerve hiring those "Bumblebees".

The dirty work has to be done, but there ain't dirty work around to be done every single day. Keepin' those idle Bumblebees around all the time is only more trouble, which is why it makes sense to carry them around and put those hands where they're needed as the train goes.

But the upper level is supposed to be responsible for those Bumblebees! We're losing spaces to live in down here with all these new people comin', and we've never seen any supplies we've earned making Blessing Boxes. They got some real nerve askin' us to make more!
Hearing this, the boy puts down the box he was folding.
[—], let's carry on. We're going to get our wage cut if we don't finish these today.
But... Hill, this box...

Stop complaining. The higher-ups said there won't be as many "tickets" to go around after this batch of Blessing Boxes is all sold, which means you'll be seeing fewer newcomers and better living conditions then.
Yeah, like, we're totes goin' to buy into that.
You think I enjoy dealing with all these?! Stop ****ing treating us like those Bumblebees' nannies!
The aristocrats always make sure I feel their rage when the Logistics Crew from the lower level has their plate full and things go south. I'm so friggin' fed up!
Maybe you want to tell 'em aristocrats to stop being so greedy, then?!
Sassing the guard, he turns around and walks into the crowd.
Whatchu all lookin' at?! No work no pay. That's right!
This workload is insane, though...

Dude, what do you have to complain about making boxes? Consider yourself lucky that you're here earning easy money. Or perhaps you want to try living as a mercenary and enjoy staring death in the eye every single day?
[—], stop looking at them. Let's just finish it.
...Alright.
Arguments, hard feelings from work, and pent-up stress...
Resentment is quietly brewing up among the people—and the boy can just feel that.
The resentment has grown so much by the time the boy has turned 11, sparing not even the dining car on the lower level that used to be the safe haven of slackers.
To help pacify their own worried souls, the adults give away half of what little food they have in exchange for homemade alcohol and cigarettes.
The kids, on the other hand, have no choice but to eat with the car reeking of alcohol and smoke.
...Bean lees soup, again. I hate it. [—], what are you holding in your hand?
Same thing, but my mom gave me a candy.
...I want one, too.
On the verge of tears and sniffing a few times, the girl looks at the boy, and then at another man beside her.
Mike...
Ain't nothing you can do about it, young lady. His mother is rich with all the dirty moola she makes, and that candy is just the tip of the iceberg.
Yo, easy with that, buddy. Julie ain't doin' anything shady!

Ain't doin' anything shady, huh? Do you even know how much money she gives those guards under the table? Any guess how her son lands himself a place with the bunch that makes Blessing Boxes and goes there all the time?
What do you mean all the time? I've only been there three times over the past few years!
The boy puts the candy before the girl.
And this candy is supposed to be my birthday gift...
Hmm...
Just take it. Pretty damn sure he's got a whole bunch of this sitting at home.
Really? Are you sure you want your niece to think it's okay to take things from people without thanking them?
With the air around them growing tense, the elder man sitting next to him eating starts looking on with a frown.
Where is Julie by the way? Still not eatin' with you? Boy, she's got some real nerve leavin' you out here on your own...
Have you all heard about all the deaths this month?
Hearing the buzz from the table next over, the elder man drops the topic and turns his gaze away.
No. What happened?
This girl from Carriage L had a cardiac arrest and died from low blood sugar...
Low blood sugar? That just means she died from hunger, no?
And these other two were killed by fallen walls when they were at a deserted park helping with reconstruction.
Did they pay compensation?

They did, but one of them had no family, so the guards took all the money. The other had his money taken away, too, because he only had a kid. The guard that took the money away promised he'd pay the child... God-only-knows how much every month.
Friggin' scumbags... They know they can do whatever the hell they please because there won't be any legal consequences...
I can't help but think they are the perps behind some of these! I mean, they probably want as many people dead as possible so they can get all the money, right?
If that scares you, you should just be like them and bring those guards a little something... They won't send you to one of those dangerous hellholes if you're in their good books.
Stealing a glance at what the Cargo Crew is eating next table over, the Bumblebees' faces grow menacing.
For ****'s sake, why does their food look so nice?
Oh, you should have seen what they had when I first got on the train, then. It was much better than this.
And they told us we'd be getting their kind of food and accommodation when we get on the train...
Bunch of lousy liars...! I swear I'm goin' to strangle every last one of them someday!
Excuse me? We aren't even the ones selling those Blessing Boxes. If you've anything to complain about, just take it to the higher-ups!
Like hell I'm gonna believe you didn't reap profit from it!
Guys, please!
Rachel looks after most of those living on the lower level—and be it the Cargo Crew or the Bumblebee, no one talks back to her when she talks.
She's their hero, leader, and a stable source of resources. She might not always have what you need when you ask her, but come back to her in a few days and she'll have what you need.
How exactly does she manage to get her hands on things when there isn't even enough to go around?
This question has been on the boy's mind for the longest time. He tried to find out how she does it by bringing up the question to her—to which she only said, "I've got extra pay here."
We can't just let things be this way forever, Capt.
I know, but like I've said before, the higher-ups are going to work with someone else if we refuse to do these Blessing Boxes, and that won't help with our situation at all.
We've tried strikes and protests... but at the end of the day, the aristocrats own this train. We won't get a say so long as they're still alive.
What are we supposed to do, then?
...Trust me, guys. We'll put it all to an end in no time.

Everyone here has had their fair share of misfortune—some have shelled away what little resources they had to buy Blessing Boxes, some have sold Blessing Boxes in exchange for shelter, while others make Blessing Boxes to secure supplies without having to put themselves in harm's way.
Blessing Boxes are like giant magnets—that, as soon as people come in contact with them, suck people into an abyss from which there is no escape.

Beyond the train lies nothing but barren land—and those who dare to venture out will find themselves embarking on a journey of endless roaming, looting, and scavenging. Who will they be able to hold accountable? And what are they supposed to do?
Believe or not to believe—that is the question, one to which no one knows the answer, allowing the status quo to prevail until someone or a group of people explodes with bottled-up rage.
